p.s: In his article John Worne uses a lot of communicative strategies and a specific typtype of language to convince the readers of his opinion.
ThisThesecommunicative strategies and language are going to be analysed in the following.
John Worne starts his article with the point, how the national view on speaking foreign languages is, to introduce the reader to the problem (cf.ll. 1-2).
In this first sentence he also uses an enumeration, which is also an exaggeration can't, won't, don't (l. 1), so the reader gets interested, what the article is about.
Furthermore John Worne uses a lot of drastic words, with that he wants to make the urgency to change something clear (cf. ll. 6-7).
Besides this Worne also uses a lot of colloquial language, to underline that he is on one level with the reader and to gain symathisympathy.
Furthermore he uses alota lot of metaphorical language, with what he wants to make the issue the UK is in clearer for the reader (cf. ll. 8-9).

For more credibiltycredibility and to underline his point of view John Worne tells about a lot of studies and statistics, to view that there are less Foreignforeign language exams every year (cf. ll. 13-17).
To convince the readers with his point of view he tells counterarguments and after he tells the argument, he says something against it (cf. ll. 18-20).

Moreover he uses irony and sarcastic language, to point out that the way of thinking that everyone speaks English in the world of business (ll. 26-27), to tell the reader that there are a lot of things we need languages for.
John Worne ends his article with an appeal, that make the readers think of what we can make against this issue (cf. ll. 47-51).
In this he also includes himself to gain sympathy and uses inclusive language, so everyone gets includeincluded in solving the problem (cf. ll. 49).
To sum it up you can say, that John Worne uses a lot of different communicative strategies, but they often have the same effect on the reader to gain sympathy and to include them.
